descriptionProfile: The warmth of cold and wild places / contributor to National Geographic Magazine / seeker of narrative
The warmth of cold and wild places / contributor to National Geographic Magazine / seeker of narrative

posts.description: Summer is coming and he won't need that hat for a while. Even during the coldest days my son never seems to feel the cold, the heat generated by running around keeps him warm in the freezing Swedish winter.

The blue stripe in this iceberg is made from denser ice, possibly a channel of frozen meltwater inside the glacier that calved it. This huge piece of ice towered above our sailing ship’s 30 metre mast. Icebergs and the calving process are normal, but multiple studies show that Greenland’s glaciers are losing mass at an accelerating pace. Climate change is real and it’s never been more important to find out more about our place in this changing system.

This year is the 10th anniversary of Earth Hour, one of the world’s biggest movements for action on climate change. I’m adding my voice to the #MakeClimateMatter online community. Sign up to take part on 25th March at 8.30pm (GMT) at wwf.org.uk/earthhour
Beautiful misty day in London's Clissold Park. Low sun meets low cloud. On the route of the historic New River which used to supply fresh water to #London. #mist

Very grateful to have this temporary view onto the world during November. This porthole is often obscured by gigantic waves and turbulent ocean water. When we reach the shelter of the South Shetland Islands and the Antarctica Peninsula the view through the porthole tells me to leave the editing and go out on deck.

A juvenile king penguin on Saunders beach in the Falkland Islands. Baby king penguins like this one will stand for a year or more on one spot while they gain their adult plumage. After their infant feathers have moulted out, hunger and instinct draws them out into the open ocean to feed for themselves.

Fall has arrived in London, leaves are just starting to drop. Performers populate the autumnal canopy of a London plane tree. This is a sequence from a piece called Calling Tree by artists Rosemary Lee and Simon Whitehead that was part of Bloomsbury Festival. #autumn #fall #art

These guys were owning the road on Vannøya in north Norway. It's a small island so they can't really go very far without taking a ferry! Not long now and these roads will be covered with snow. The hardy birch trees that line the hills are starting to release their leaves to the fierce coastal winds.
Love these birds. Maybe I'll hold off on the caption writing, see if you can tell me what species they are. Extra points if you can guess where I made the picture.

Scientists I worked with called this 'The Spider', it was used in an ocean acidification experiment. "Ocean acidi.. what ??" I hear you say. As if there wasn't enough earth/climate stuff to worry about. Yes it's complicated, which is why Maike from GEOMAR has launched an amazing project to tell the story in pictures. Click the link in my profile to get learning and enjoy seeing more photography. Text is in English and German.
Playing checkers with Kittiwakes in the Arctic. Looking through netting on the stern of a ship while these birds gather in search of food.
